abstract.p: Host susceptibility to periodontal infection is controlled by genetic factors. As a step toward identifying and cloning these factors, we generated an A/J x BALB/cJ F2 mouse resource population. A genome-wide search for Quantitative Trait Loci (QTL) associated with periodontitis was performed. We aimed to quantify the phenotypic response of the progenies to periodontitis by microCT analysis, to perform a genome-wide search for QTL associated with periodontitis, and, finally, to suggest candidate genes for periodontitis. We were able to produce 408 F2 mice. All mice were co-infected with Porphyromonas gingivalis and Fusobacterium nucleatum bacteria. Six weeks following infection, alveolar bone loss was quantified by computerized tomography (microCT) technology. We found normal distribution of the phenotype, with 2 highly significant QTL on chromosomes 5 and 3. A third significant QTL was found on chromosome 1. Candidate genes were suggested, such as Toll-like receptors (TLR) 1 and 6, chemokines, and bone-remodeling genes (enamelin, ameloblastin, and amelotin). This report shows that periodontitis in mice is a polygenic trait with highly significant mapped QTL.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Periodontitis, the most common chronic inflammatory disease in humans, results in the destruction of tooth-supporting tissues and eventual tooth loss. The process is characterized by permanent damage of periodontal ligament, formation of periodontal pockets, and alveolar bone resorption (Williams, 1990). The disease is initiated by bacteria that accumulate in a subgingival biofilm, becoming pathogenic for the host and stimulating an inflammatory response in the host gingiva (Wilson, 1995). An excessive or sustained response leads to chronic inflammation, recruiting humoral and cellular components of the immune system, including high levels of inflammatory cytokines, tissue-destructive enzymes and prostaglandins, as well as low levels of anti-inflammatory cytokines (Page et al., 2000; Kornman et al., 1997).

Individuals are not equally affected by the accumulation of subgingival bacterial plaque; some are very susceptible and develop aggressive forms of periodontitis, some are less affected and develop chronic periodontitis. Others are resistant and never develop the disease (Kinane and Hart, 2003). There is a significant genetic component associated with the susceptibility to chronic periodontitis (Baker and Roopenian, 2002; Baker, Evans, Roopenian, 1994; Baker, Dixon, Roopenian, 2000; Meisel et al., 2001; Stabholz et al., 2010), with 38% of the population variance attributed to genetic factors and a high concordance in monozygotic twins (Michalowicz, 1994; Michalowicz et al., 2000). Numerous studies have investigated genetic polymorphisms in relation to both aggressive periodontitis and chronic periodontitis. Most genes known to be associated with periodontitis in humans are also linked to the immune response. These include genes that affect the expression of interleukin-1, interleukin-6, tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-10, E-selectins, Fc-gamma receptor, CD14, Toll-like receptors, caspase recruitment domain 15, and vitamin D receptor (Laine et al., 2012). However, we are still far from understanding the genetic basis of chronic periodontitis (Kinane and Hart, 2003) or defining the specific loci and genes involved in host susceptibility to the disease in humans.

Controlled and standardized investigations of susceptibility to infectious disease are difficult in humans, due to the difficulty in controlling the challenge to the host response, and because susceptibility is determined by the interactions of numerous genetic loci and environmental factors (i.e., bacteria) and lifestyle factors (like smoking and nutrition). In contrast, susceptibility can be investigated under controlled conditions in inbred mouse strains. Importantly, the majority of murine genes have human homologs, so that the results obtained in mice can be translated to humans.

In genetically defined strains of mice, chromosomal regions responsible for the genetic variance of complex traits can be mapped as quantitative trait loci (QTL) in experimental populations available for precise study under defined conditions. Once QTL or genes are identified in a mouse model, genetic analysis and cloning of the orthologue genes can then be extended to humans.

The classic method (F2 intercross population) for conducting a genome-wide search for QTL underlying infectious diseases was adopted in our research (Iraqi, 2000; Yi and Banerjee, 2009). The second filial generation, derived from the intercross of F1 generation, exhibited, for the first time, a mixed chromosome of the 2 inbred founders (“P” generation). The homologous chromosomes of the commercial inbred lines were first recombined to form new combinations of genes during the chromosomal crossover in the meiosis, to form the F2 generation. In the search for a polygenic trait (attributable to 2 or more genes and their interaction with the environment), many polygenic traits can be depicted by a bell curve, because they are controlled by many genes and result in gradations where each gene has an effect. The F2 population is an adequate source for the investigation of QTL. The population exhibits a wide range of phenotypic response, as a result of interactions within these QTL and the environment (Ronin et al., 1999).
Here, we initiated murine model periodontitis by a mixed infection of 2 anaerobic bacteria in an F2 population for mapping QTL associated with host susceptibility to the disease.

sec.title: Mouse Populations
sec.p: In total, 408 A/J x BALB/c F2 mice were generated. Based on the results of a previous study (Baker et al., 2000), inbred mouse strains BALB/cJ and A/J were confirmed to be susceptible and resistant, respectively, to periodontitis.

All experimental mice and protocols were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of HUJHH (approval number: MD-08-10913-3), which adhere to the Israeli guidelines, which follow NIH/USA animal care and use protocols. Students monitored the infected mice daily for overall health status. Mice which were observed to suffer (less movement and activity) from the infection, and based on consultation with the veterinarian at the animal unit, were terminated. The termination procedure for mice during infection-based animal suffering or at the endpoint of the experiment was based on the injection of Ketamine and Xylazine at a dose of 100 mg/kg (body weight) and 10 mg/kg (body weight), respectively, for initial euthanasia, and subsequently by cervical dislocation. The article was prepared according to ARRIVE guidelines.

sec.title: Bacterial Cultivation
sec.p: Porphyromonas gingivalis strain ATCC 33277 and Fusobacterium nucleatum strain PK 1594 were grown in peptone yeast extract containing hemin and vitamin K (Wilkins Chalgren broth, Oxoid Ltd, Basingstoke, UK), in an anaerobic chamber with 85% N2, 5% H2, and 10% CO2, followed by 3 washes in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). The bacterial concentration was spectrophotometrically standardized to OD650nm = 0.1 for P. gingivalis, corresponding to 1010 bacteria/mL (Genco et al., 1991), and OD660nm = 0.26 for F. nucleatum, corresponding to 109 bacteria/mL (Kolenbrander and Andersen, 1989). This step was necessary to count the bacteria that were grown. Before the infection, the 2 bacteria were mixed together. The ratio was 1:1 (Pg: Fn), and 109 CFU were used.

sec.title: Infection
sec.p: The infection procedure was initiated in mice at the age of 7 to 8 wks. First, mice were treated with sulfamethoxazole (10 mL/500 mL water ad libitum for 10 days, followed by a three-day wash-out, antibiotic-free period), before 3 applications of the oral co-infection containing P. gingivalis and F. nucleatum (109 of each bacterium in a total of 400 µL per mouse) at days 0, 2, and 4 (control mouse groups were treated with PBS), with 2% carboxymethylcellulose in PBS (Polak et al., 2009). At 42 days post-infection, the maxillae were harvested for microCT analysis. This protocol showed consistent results for different batches. Our histological results indicated a chronic inflammatory process that persisted continuously after the infection was introduced to the animal.

sec.title: Phenotype Determination by MicroCT
sec.p: Maxillary hemi-jaws were analyzed by compact fan-beam-type computerized tomography (µCT 40, Scanco Medical, Bassersdorf, Switzerland). The samples were placed in a cylindrical sample holder, and 200 microtomographic slices with increments of 12 µm were acquired, covering the entire bucco-palatal width of each hemi-jaw. A reference line was set throughout the microtomographic slices at a set distance from the cemento-enamel junction. After the reference line was defined, the microCT reconstructed the hemi-jaw to calculate the residual coronal alveolar bone volume from the slices (Fig 1.). The results are presented as the residual bone volume above the reference line in mm3 (Wilensky et al., 2005). These measurements served as the phenotype in our study.

caption.p: Left hemi-maxilla reconstructed by micro-CT. Both panels show a buccal view of a hemi-maxilla, reconstructed by microCT, of a periodontitis-resistant mouse (A) compared with that of a periodontitis-susceptible mouse (B) from the F2 population (both mice were co-infected with P. gingivalis and F. nucleatum). Only hard tissue can be seen after reconstruction by microCT (tooth parts and bone). Horizontal resorption can be seen as differences between the resistant and susceptible mice.

sec.title: F2 Heritability Calculation
sec.p: The variation within the purebred parental lines is a measure of the environmental variance. The variance within the F2 is a measure of the total variance (environmental + genetic). The genetic variance was calculated as follows:
where H2 is the heritability, Vg is the genetic variance, and Ve is the environmental variance.

sec.title: Genotyping and QTL Analysis
sec.p: Employing a selective genotyping approach, which had been proposed earlier (Darvasi and Soller, 1994; Ronin et al., 1999) and confirmed successfully in a variety of studies (Iraqi et al., 2000, 2003; Menge et al., 2003; Hernandez-Valladares et al., 2004), we genotyped only the phenotypic extremes (high and low residual alveolar bone volume) of the response, aiming to identify QTL affecting resistance and susceptibility to periodontal disease.

In total, 150 mice, 38% of the F2 population (high and low), were genotyped (DNA was extracted from tail tissue for each mouse individually by the urea lysate method) at the Wellcome Trust Human Genome Center, UK, with a set of 170 mouse Illumina single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) linkage panels, by the Golden Gate Assay on a Universal-32 Beadchip genotyping platform, which differentiates between the parental lines across the whole genome. We used HAPPY software (Mott et al., 2000) for QTL mapping and to determine the gene effect and its mode.

sec.title: Candidate Genes
sec.p: Candidate genes within the mapped loci were identified from the public database http://www.informatics.jax.org/, based on their known location and function.

sec.title: Susceptibility to Periodontal Co-infection with P. gingivalis and F. nucleatum
sec.p: Consistency of infection across all batches was tested by one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). The differences among the infected replicates were not significant (p = .569), whereas the differences among all the groups, including the control, were highly significant (p = .004). Thus, our protocol shows consistent results. Other studies (Baker, Evans, Roopenian, 1994; Baker, Dixon, Roopenian, 2000), using the same protocol and colony-forming unit (CFU), reported that P. gingivalis could be isolated from infected mice up to 42 days post-infection. In our laboratory, we have identified both P. gingivalis and F. nucleatum 42 days post-infection using nested PCR (unpublished observations). We found that periodontal tissue from sham-infected mice shows high fiber in histological analysis, and low cellular and low blood vessel content. Periodontal tissue from mixed infected mice shows significant enlargement, loss of fibrous integrity, hyperemia, and cell accumulation, indicating a chronic inflammatory process that persisted long after the infection was introduced to the animal (data not shown).

The F2 population exhibited a virtually normal distribution of residual alveolar bone volume: 30 x 10-4 to 140 x 10-4 mm3, mean, 83 x 10-4 mm3 (Fig. 2). Interestingly, of the 408 F2 mice tested, 37 (9%) had a lower bone volume (after infection) than the initial mean value of the naïve susceptible strain BALB/cJ (62 x 10-4 mm3), whereas 42 (10.3%) exceeded the initial mean value of the naïve resistant strain, A/J (103 x 10-4 mm3). The mean bone volume of the F1 naïve and infected animals was intermediate between that of the corresponding parental lines (Fig. 2). The residual bone volume (92 x 10-4 mm3) of the infected mice was not significantly different from that of the uninfected F1 mice (92 x 10-4), suggesting that the F1 population was resistant to infection.

caption.p: (left) Distribution of residual alveolar bone volume in 408 A/J x BALB/cJ F2 mice. (right) Residual alveolar bone volume of inbred lines in F1 and F2 mouse populations. Each of the 2 inbred lines (A/J and BALB/cJ) and the F1 population (first generation) are represented by 2 columns. The left (black) column represents the control group (non-infected), and the right (gray) column represents the infected groups. The F2 infected mouse population is represented by 3 single gray columns [mean, high, and low (12.5% each)]. The F1 population shows a resistant phenotype, as previously described (Baker et al., 2000). The F2 population displays a high diversity in the phenotypic response to the infection. Nos. of mice: n (A/J control) = 7; n (A/J infection) = 7; n (BALB/C control) = 6; n (F1 control) = 7; n (A/J control) = 7; n (F2 mean) = 395; and n (F2 12.5%) = 50.

sec.title: F2 Periodontitis QTL
sec.p: To maximize our ability to detect QTL contributing to the variations in the responses to periodontitis, we genotyped only the phenotypic extremes of the F2 animals (high and low, 20% each) (Darvasi and Soller, 1994). Genome-wide association analysis detected 2 highly significant QTL on chromosomes 5 and 3, negative log10 p value (logP) 4.79 and 3.93, respectively, with genome-wide significance (Fig. 3). Both peaks exceeded 95% genome-wide significance (logP = 3.5) based on logP permutation analysis. A third significant QTL was mapped on chromosome 1 (Fig. 3), with logP 2.47, at 50% genome-wide significance (logP = 2.3). The inheritance of QTL on chromosome 1 proved to be recessive, which means that the phenotype is seen only in the homozygote genotype, whereas the QTL on chromosomes 3 and 5 were additive, indicating that the phenotype strengthened from heterozygote genotype to homozygote genotype status.

caption.p: Genome scan of periodontal infection in mice. The x-axis shows chromosome number, and the y-axis shows, the statistical significance of the association, measured as −log (p value). The horizontal lines represent genome-wide significance thresholds of E = 0.50 (lower line), 0.10 (middle line), and 0.05 (upper line), derived by permutation (E = percentage of permutations in which the genome-wide maximum did not exceed the threshold). Two highly significant QTL (E < 0.05) were mapped on chromosomes 3 and 5 and one significant QTL (E < 0.5) on chromosome 1.

sec.p: The QTL on chromosomes 1, 3, and 5 account for about 25% of the phenotypic variance (Table). A search of the mouse genome database showed that there are about 200 genes in the highly significant QTL, and a total of 483 genes within all 3 mapped QTL.

fn.p: Our QTL were labeled as Perio 1 to 3. These QTL can account for about 25% of the phenotypic variance found in the F2 population. The locations of the QTL and their genomic intervals are listed in the Table, according to different significance levels (the same QTL, with a lower significance level, harbor a higher number of genes). There are about 200 genes underlying the 2 highly significant QTL, and a total of 483 genes within all the QTL.
E = percentage of permutations in which the genome-wide maximum did not exceed the threshold.

sec.title: Heritability Calculation
sec.p: Heritability of bone loss, which measures the variance between and within tested groups, for the F2 population, based on the difference in the phenotype variance between the 2 parental inbred strains, was calculated as 0.72.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study demonstrates periodontitis as a polygenic trait in mice. The apparently simple resistance genetic architecture observed in the F1 generation masks the more complex architecture in the F2 generation, which most likely is due to heterosis. It is known that when inbred lines of mice are crossed, the progeny often exhibit phenotypic variation or present novel traits that were not present in the parental strains. This indicates that the inbred strains of mice harbor a tremendous amount of natural genetic variation, greater than that seen when the lines themselves are compared. Our F2 population exhibited a virtually normal distribution of residual alveolar bone volume. We found mice that were more susceptible than the inbred BALB/c strain. However, interestingly, we observed the presence of mice that exhibited even greater residual alveolar bone volume after infection than the resistant A/J strain. This may be attributed to the new genetic architecture of the F2 population compared with that of the founders. Overall, our 3 QTL can account for 25% of the phenotypic variance among the F2 population (Table).

Although the mapping resolution of the QTL is relatively low, some speculation can be made regarding candidate causal genes within the mapped QTL intervals. Here we focused on the most significant QTL on chromosome 5 (which account for about 11% of the phenotypic variance). The most likely candidate genes fall into 2 groups:

(a) immunity factors including TLR 1 and TLR 6. TLR genes are well-known to be associated with innate immunity and host response to infectious diseases and are important in the elimination of invading pathogens. TLR genes have been suggested as candidate genes in humans (Laine et al., 2012). TLRs are members of the pattern-recognition receptor (PRR) family and play a central role in the initiation of the innate cellular immune response and, subsequently, the adaptive immune response to pathogens (Ozinsky et al., 2000). Activation of the TLR signal initiates a pathway leading to activation of a variety of genes that function in the host defense mechanism, including inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and antigen-presenting molecules. Five of these are chemokine (C-X-C motif) ligands (Cxcl1, Cxcl2, Cxcl3, Cxcl5, and Cxcl15), which lie within this QTL (Smith and Herschman, 1995; Luan et al., 2001). The different interactions between these genes can lead to the phenotypic variations we measured.

(b) bone-remodeling factors, including enamelin, ameloblastin, and amelotin. The function of these genes is not completely understood, but they are probably modulators of mineral formation and crystal elongation in enamel. They might also affect osteogenic mineralization, bone remodeling, and repair in craniofacial bones (Hu et al., 1998; Tamburstuen et al., 2011) (a list of all genes in QTL of chromosome 5 is available in the Appendix Table). Fine mapping and candidate gene validation will be necessary to identify the causal genes in these mice.

In conclusion, we uncovered 2 highly significant (higher than 95% genome-wide significant) loci on chromosomes 5 and 3, and one significant (higher than 50% genome-wide significant) locus on chromosome 1. This study is a first step in the use of mouse models of periodontitis to detect candidate genes. To reveal candidate genes, fine mapping of the QTL should be carried out, together with gene expression and validation. Use of other populations of mice such as the Collaborative Cross (Churchill et al., 2004) may uncover further QTL and corroborate the findings reported here.

ack.p: We thank Prof. Morris Soller and Prof. Itzhak Ofek for their advice, guidance, and discussion.
